The project seeks to improve human development outcomes among targeted ethnic groups through strengthening institutional support mechanisms and linkages to facilitate and encourage needs-based response at community level.
first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: - Disseminate and promote project results; - Set up a SSC project with Nepal CO in fundraising for the Nepalese earthquake victims through Yi-Nepal initiative by selling the cross-over products made by Yi and Nepal communities.

- The new component of the Project, the Nepal part has been implemented through UNDP Nepal Office. The component aims to support the development of micro and small enterprises in Nepal. - A collection of cross-culture artisan products combing Yi embroidery from Yongren Country of Yunnan Province and Pashmina from Nepal was launched at Shanghai Fashion Show. The theme of this event was “Lost Reappear”. It aims to create an opportunity for community-to-community based empowerment and enable participants from Nepal and Yi Minority to explore their different traditions and learn from each other to support low-income women entrepreneurs. Senior representatives from China Women’s Development Foundation (CWDF), Mary Kay, UNDP, Deputy Director, Shanghai Municipal Commission of Commerce, and Ministry of Industry of Nepali government participated in press conference of the launch.
- Deliver a training session

description.narrative: The project has integrated the government and enterprise resources for preserving and developing the unique natural and cultural environment of ethnic area. It supports to establish a female entrepreneurship program for ethnic minorities in Yunnan
populated place

activity-description.narrative: This activity takes place in Chuxiong.

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

1.1 Establish an Association of Yi Embroidery Industry in Mouding County 1.2 Competition for Minority Handicraft Entrepreneurship 1.3 Training – Capacity Building and Enhancement 1.4 Excavate and compile the traditional culture and crafts skills of the Yi people, and publish those documentations to protect and inherit the Yi culture. 1.5 Provide training for the local government officials and social workers engaged in the development of cultural industries, with special attentions to women' employment and entrepreneurship development.
2.1 Build rose plantation demonstration base with coverage of around seventy mu 2.2 Introduce the concept of fair trade to the rose plantation base.
3.1 Cooperate with local government in holding policy workshops on entrepreneurship development of minority youth and women, through which to promote development of relevant policies and institutions, encourage and support entrepreneurship and the employment of local youth and women. 3.2 Organize research on the employment conditions, challenges and responses regarding the youth and women in ethnic minority regions, policy recommendations and submit to governmental department.
4.1 Build a platform to organize entrepreneurial exchanges on ethnic arts and crafts; select products to participate in local or national cultural to raise the public cognition of cultural products. 4.2 Document success stories and achievements, and communicate project results to a broader circle of potential partners and the general public.

comment.narrative: - The embroidery business is based on family workshops, small in scale, limited in products and underdeveloped in product innovations; there is a lack of leading enterprises, and a market-oriented, advantaged and featured leading industry yet to be formed. While local minority women want to increase their revenue, the cultural, educational and geographical constraints make it difficult to increase revenue and secure financial support. - Based on the unique cultural and geographical conditions of the minority region, one goal of the project is to develop advantageous industries, protect local ecological environment and increase income of the farmers; at the same time, to explore the model of fair trade on agricultural products, enhance relevant systems, promote the mutual cooperation and positive interaction between farmers and enterprises, provide the employment opportunities the rural women, increase farmers' income and promote economic development in rural regions.

- A Yi embroidery Association will be established for capacity building. - Rose planting demonstration base will be established for production skills training. 8 household of base will increase their income. - Hold policy workshops. Put forward policy. - Staff training, coordination meeting, and staff regular meeting. - Number of staff trained through the training exercise.

- Maintain the Yi Embroidery Industry in Mouding County for capacity building - Collect and disseminate information on the Yi culture to the public - Establish a rose planting demonstration base for capacity building

title.narrative: Strengthen Capacity of Poverty Reduction Centre (IPRCC)

description.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of the International Poverty Reduction Center in China for South-South Cooperation

Through the project, the International Poverty Reduction Center in China's institutional development will be further strengthened and South-South cooperation for poverty reduction of other developing countries promoted.
capital of a political entity

Indicators 1. IPRCC seen by end of project as a global knowledge hub for consistent information, knowledge and training on income and human poverty reduction. Training packages, currently produced on an ad hoc basis are professionalized and systematized and feedback on training regularly assessed. A set of core elements for training courses developed. Quality of publications and research meet higher international standards verified by international advisory board. At least 50% of documents and publications translated into English. On line training is available and accessed by at least 5 countries. At least 10 staff per year sent overseas for international exposure to training/study tours, conferences, research and knowledge sharing. A lasting human resource development strategy and internal capacity building master plan defined and applied. 2. Center’s activities strategically linked to a network of poverty and development focused national and international institutions and IPRCC trainee alumni and well integrated into relevant global knowledge networks; Increased opportunities for real and/or virtual dialogue and debate on pro-poor policy issues generated through annual forums with international media coverage beyond China, workshops and other active dissemination, publication and communication in China and cross recipient countries. At least 200 individuals from at least 20 developing countries in Asia and the Pacific region, Latin America and Africa and 200 individuals from China representing a cross-section of government and non-governmental institutions receive tailored training on poverty reduction and pro-poor development strategies and lessons. Gender equality is addressed in training contents, trainer and trainee as well as other beneficiary composition. IPRCC hosts at least two full-time research fellows (one international) and two short-term visiting scholars per year, one national research/training manager or coordinator.

comment.narrative:
1. Limited institutional and management capacity to accommodate demand from other developing economies to learn from China’s experience of poverty reduction and systemize training responses; limited capacity with respect to knowledge management, publication of research and sharing of experience and knowledge on poverty reduction and meeting the MDGs; Translation capacities are poor. Lessons on China’s poverty reduction related information, research and field experience scattered among national institutions. Lack of systemic knowledge of developing country situations and needs. Disconnection between poverty-focused applied research, needs-based training, pro-poor policy formulation and implementation
2. Formal linkages with other research institutions and think tanks not well established for purposes of exchange of experience and lessons and with limited sharing and collaboration across institutions and countries. Mechanisms for South-South cooperation not formalized either with institution or government. Limited knowledge and understanding of recipient countries about China’s experiences and in poverty reduction, needs for addressing multiple dimensions of poverty and better understanding of poverty-reduction impacts of macro-policies for pro-poor policy design and implementation; Strategic linkages between targeted, regional and macro level interventions in China and recipient countries not in place

1. Exchanges training benefited to other developing countries in sharing China’s development experience. And Knowledge products, such as studies on selected topics relating to poverty reduction and social development, produced and disseminated during the forums and seminar. IPRCC capacity building needs assessed and addressed through staff exchange programme. 2. High level dialogues and regional forums organized to promote poverty reduction and inclusive development, such as International Poverty Reduction Forum, China-ASEAN Forum, China-Africa Conference. Strengthened partnerships with research institutes and international organizations.

- Coordination of relevant government divisions, research institutes and private stakeholders strengthened; - Two Internet-based Farmers Service and Training Centres built to enhance the agriculture extension capability; - Increased awareness, in both public and private sectors, of the social, economical and ecological benefits of effective sand control, responsible use of soil and water resources and self-motivated sustainable development. - Established a market-lead value-added fruits and vegetable production industry, characterized by organic production and low carbon emissions. - A 5-year watershed management master plan developed to include the grass land, water courses, forests, farms and road system into one integrated ecological and social-economic zone. - Real-life demonstration regions with regenerated ecosystems and improved livelihood - Successful practices to other part of China and the rest of the world.

capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: This activity takes place in Beijing.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

- Establish national voluntary emission reduction project registry system In order to maintain a regulated, fair, open, transparent and credible voluntary emission reduction trading market, this project will design, build and operationalize a national voluntary emission reduction project registry system. - Establish a national registry for regional and nationwide emissions trading schemes In order to materialize the national objective to build carbon market gradually, this project intends to design and establish a national registry system for future emissions trading schemes. - The project intends to build and enhance the capacities of stakeholders in the voluntary project market, and regional and national emissions trading market. The project will carry out education and training activities to complement the execution of The Tentative Management Method for China’s Voluntary GHG Reduction Trading Activities. The training is targeted to relevant policy and technical personals in institutions and trading-related personals. Local government and non-government organizations will receive trainings as well. The capacity building covers soft and hardware capacity.

1. Contribute to an effective and efficient allowance allocation system of national carbon market through meetings, workshops, study tours, commenting on draft documents and ongoing dialogue. 2.Contribute to implementation plan for China's national ETS on provincial level through meetings, workshops, study tours, commenting on draft documents and ongoing dialogue. 3. 1. During 2016 there has been some meetings with Tsinghua University regarding the status of the allocation process in China's national ETS. However, most of our contribution to this outcome will be in 2017 and 2018, since the objective of this outcome is improvement of the allocation methods that has been under preparation in 2016. 2. During 2016 we have had continuous dialogue with NCSC especially regarding output 2.2 and 2.3. We joined a field investigation in Beijing Pilot in June 2016, where we learned how Beijing Pilot has implemented and put into operations it's ETS. In October 2016 we joined a field study tour to Chengdu, which is a non-pilot, to learn how they had prepared for the national ETS. In November we arranged a study tour for NCSC to Norway/the Netherlands and Brussels. The aim of this study tour was that NSCS should learn from the EU ETS experience on implementation plans, and the different role of the Commission and it's Member States. 3. During 2016 we have had continuous dialogue with Sino Carbon regarding activity 3.1 (standardized training material) and 3.2 ("help-desk"). Sino Carbon has regularly given us the status on these activities, and we have given comments on both the training materials and the idea for the "help-desk". In 2016 we started planning the industry peer learning workshop (activity 3.3.2) that will take place in 2017. The workshop was postponed from 2016 to 2017. 4. During 2016 we have had continuous dialogue with Sino Carbon regarding activity 4.1. Sino Carbon has given us the status on this activity and we have had discussions on the preliminary outputs from activity 4.1. We have also discussed some challenges on making a Carbon Trading Info Platform. We were to see preliminary drafts and sketches of the info platform I 2016. This is prone to early 2017.

comment.narrative: On 20 April 2013, a 7-magnitude earthquake hit the Lushan County of Ya’an City in Sichuan Province. As of 23 April, 193 people have reported dead, 25 still missing and 12,211 injured. 1.99 million people in total of 115 counties have been affected. As of 23 April, 3,509 aftershocks were recorded and at least 100 aftershocks were 3.0 magnitudes and above. Over 99% of houses in the epicenter, Longmen Township of Lushan County collapsed, and local infrastructure were badly damaged. Shortly after the earthquake, UN Resident Coordinator in China extended her condolences and offered UN support to the Government of China. On 21 April, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon expressed his deepest sympathies to Chinese government and people. He pledged “the UN is ready to provide assistance and to mobilize any international support that may be needed”. UN agencies are in coordination with their line government agencies and collating information on damage and loss. To support the UN in joining relief activities, Bureau for Crisis Prevention and Recovery (BCPR) has approved USD 100,000 from the Immediate Response Category (II) of TRAC 1.1.3. The fund will be utilized to reinforce the coordination efforts and needs assessments. The Government of China is mounting all-out efforts in rescuing affected people and allocating life-saving materials to the areas. On July 20, Sichuan Provincial Government officially released 11 plans on post-disaster reconstruction including strategy of integrating disaster reduction during the phase of early recovery. Ya’an earthquake struck the same area where people had experienced the devastating Wenchuan earthquake in 2008. While the Government is putting all efforts in saving lives and assessing the casualties and economic losses, the absence of needs-based impact assessment in the overall post-disaster evaluation may lead to incomplete pictures and overlook the real needs behind the physical damage and loss. Therefore it is important for UNDP
NA

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1.Improved protection and management of Hainan’s ecosystems through expansion, consolidation and sustainable financing of the provincial PA system. 2. Strengthened protection, participatory management and restoration of mangrove forests through the development of a Mangrove PA Network (MPAN) 3. Improved integration of wetland conservation into development and sectoral planning and practices through a strengthened PA System Management Framework including economic valuation of ecosystem services.

comment.narrative: Insufficient PA coverage, operational financing and systemic and institutional capacity at provincial level 2. Limited tools and capacities for wetland PA site management 3.Disconnect between wetland PA sub-system management and development planning and sectoral planning

1. Provincial guidelines for management and zoning of coastal wetland PAs. 2. Protection status of mangrove PAs strengthened through network. 3. Awareness raised of the economic value of mangrove wetland ecosystem service.

1.A pilot national wetland park in Sanya, which is called Sanya Donghe Wetland Park, was approved by SFA with an area of 528 ha in Dec. 2016. By far, Hainan terrestrial PAs is increased by 31,277 ha and the total terrestrial PAs is 316,977ha. 2. A draft of "Hainan Regulation on Wetland Conservation" was developed by the Hainan Wild Plan and Animal Protection Bureau and the PMO. The provincial government organized an expert consultation meeting to comment on the draft. Further studies are planned by HFD on further improvement on the draft in 2017.

Indicator 1.1: Financing Plan for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem. Indicator 2.1: Operational MPAN is evident through: i) Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans. ii) Network coordination centre and training base established at DongzhaigangNNR iii) All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols. Indicator 2.5: Viable alternative options are demonstrated for target communities impacting mangrove resources at Dongzhaigang and Qinglangang that result in more sustainable resource use and include the equitable representation and involvement of women. Indicator 3.1: Sector specific standards for tourism and coastal fisheries are consistent with international standards for responsible ecotourism and fishery practices. Indicator 3.5: Improved data sharing platform for Hainan wetland PAs is established, regularly updated and in frequent use by a range of data providers and target audiences

In 2013 Hainan Forestry Department promoted the establishment of 1 national forest park and approved the establishment of 12 provincial forest parks The coverage of Hainan terrestrial PAs has been increased by 29516 ha
From 2014 till now 2 new provincial nature reserves are in the process of applying for approval which are Exianling NR forest ecosystem with an area of 4490ha and Yanding NR mangrove ecosystem with an area of 160ha A privatelyowned wetland park Baolinggang WP with an area of about 100ha is now under design and planned to start construction by end of 2015 The wetland park is owned by a renowned real estate company Luneng Group and they are keen to follow the ecological concept in the wetland park construction with the support of the project A memorandum of understanding is drafted by the Project to include the wetland park as one demonstration site of Hainan GEF project However the area of vegetation type is not yet updated because the Hainan PA Master Plan is not yet approved and this category was not applied during the 2nd National Wetland Inventory Assessment This issue will be put forward during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015

For major activities of the project such as the Bird Festival in Dongzhaigang and the MWPAN establishment meeting media were invited to report Moreover with efforts of the communication specialist reports about birds wetland resources mangroves can frequently be seen in the newspaper In addition news about project activities was also released on the UNDP China official website

In the beginning of 2015 two major awarenessraising events were cohosted by the project with Hainan Forestry Department which is the celebration of World Wetland Day in Feburary and the BirdLoving Week and the World Wildlife Day in March According to official statistics in total 25 thousand visitors attended the two events which mostly were urban residents students from primary and middle school government officials NGOs etc

description.narrative: Establishment of a suitable crosssectoral body at provincial level to facilitate mainstreaming of wetland conservation into sectoral policies plans and practices

comment.narrative: Coordination between wetland PA subsystem management and development planning and sectoral planning occurs but is largely responsive and ad hoc

A permanent crosssectoral body is established at provincial level formally recognized by all sectors and proactively promoting and facilitating strategic intersectoral coordination on wetland conservation

To promote cross sectoral cooperation and the wetland mainstreaming the project has encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities Moreover crosssectoral meetings and training workshops with relevant local government agencies including environment water resources tourism marine and fishery forestry were organized in Wenchang Dongfang Danzhou Sanya Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i learn about the project ii have some technical capacity building part to it iii also facilitate sharing and mutual learning
To establish a specialized crosssectoral body on wetland conservation is perceived to be of little chance because there are already many such bodies on different issues which are mainly related to a specific national project of significance So that during the 2nd PSC meeting it was approved that the crosssectoral body will be built on the current PSC by trying to include more government departments

description.narrative: Improved data sharing platform for Hainans wetland PAs is established regularly updated and in frequent use by a range of data providers and target audiences

comment.narrative: Data on Hainans wetland PAs are dispersed largely unavailable online and not regularly updated
A centralized database on Hainans wetland PAs is accessible to online users updated on a monthly basis and registers at least 100 hits per month

To develop an online database platform the Project contracted the Network Research Development Dept NRDD of Research Institute of Forest Resource Information Techniques under Chinese Academy of Forestry After several rounds of discussion together with the NR management and NRDD the content of the database was formulated and the first draft of the database platform is foreseen in Sept 2015

13th 5year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism including the Hainan International Tourism Island Master Plan fisheries water resources and other key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

To promote wetland mainstreaming the project encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities Moreover crosssectoral meetings with relevant local government agencies including environment water resources tourism marine and fishery forestry were organized in Wenchang Dongfang and Sanya during the CTA visit in Hainan Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i learn about the project ii have some technical capacity building part to it iii also facilitate sharing and learning amongst each other

Approval and demonstrated voluntary uptake of sector specific standards for tourism by 20 companies based on ecotourism category of the ASEAN Tourism Standards and coastal fisheries by 2 villages based on the FAO Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and related guidelines

The project had contacted Haikou Tourism Development Committee to get the draft Regulation on the Management of Mangrove and Rural Tourism Zone Further study is to be made to look into the existing regulations and plans

description.narrative: Increase in the number of wintering Blackfaced Spoonbills Platalea minor in Hainan

comment.narrative: Wintering population of 76 BF Spoonbills
Wintering population of 100 BF Spoonbills with a stable or increasing trend

According to the result of the International Blackfaced Spoonbill Census in every January the number in Hainan slightly increased from 44 in 2012 to 56 in 2015
In Aug 2014 the local government planted about 573ha of mangrove seedling on the mudflat and beach inside the NR for the purpose of restoring mangrove forest and attracting more BF spoonbill However according to bird specialists the planting efforts may have a negative impact So based on the specialists advice and previous studies on BF spoonbill the project wrote an advice letter to the local government In addition during CTAs visits to Dongfang this issue was openly discussed among the government officials Now the government was highly aware of the problem and willing to take measures to make change

During the inception workshop the target of 1000 ha for mangrove replanting was perceived to be unrealistic because the available land in NRs are very limited So it was proposed to change the wording of mangrove replanting into mangrove wetland restoration However the approval procedure of this revision is not completed So this issue will be rediscussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office
Moreover during the project implementation it was found that the government stressed too much on mangrove replanting instead of restoring the ecosystem service functions of mangrove wetland Even worse fastgrowing exotic mangrove species were commonly used in the replanting To resolve the problem in March 2014 the project organized a mangrove restoration expert discussion workshop at the provincial level and in May and June 4 trainings were conducted for officials from different government apartments in Sanya Danzhou Dongfang and Wenchang

In Dec 26 2014 the establishment meeting of the MWPAN was held in Haikou Directors from 10 project sites and the deputy director from Hainan Wild Animal and Plant Conservation Bureau which is responsible for Hainan PAs management attended the meeting The Declaration of the Network was discussed approved and signed by all member PAs on the meeting The declaration states that the Network will organize at least one meeting per year and a theme will be selected during the meeting which is to be the key focus for all member PAs for the year The theme for 2015 is biodiversity monitoring A timetable for monthly monitoring was agreed upon by all members
Necessary equipment including meeting room audiovisual equipment professional cameras for bird photography and computers etc were procured for the establishment of a training center in Dongzhaigang in the second half of 2014 After that a training event was organized in Dongzhaigang on species identification and monitoring in Nov 2014

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. the protection of wetland ecosystems with PA planning and management enhanced in XUAR through systemic, legal and institutional capacity strengthening 2. The biodiversity of AMWL is effectively conserved with a strengthened PA network and enhanced operational budget through adoption of a landscape approach to conservation planning and environmental management 3. The adoption and development of a ‘community co-management’ approach to conservation in Liangheyuan NR demonstrates improved management effectiveness for a wetland PA in the Altai Mountains and Wetland Landscape

comment.narrative: 1. Insufficient systemic and institutional capacity at provincial level to plan and manage the PA system and the sub-system of wetland PAs 2. Disconnect between the management ofPA systems and development and sectoral planningprocesses at the Altai landscape level3. Limited nature reserve staff capacities and limited community participation in PA management

1.Completion of guidelines; report of standard analysis; Attendants of the meeting 2. Increase awareness of the protection and sustainable development 3. Completion of management plan, monitoring plan and the monitoring station, the management system; Indicator 2.1 (1): Number of Climate change policies (regulations, ordinances, guidelines, etc.) identified and up taken up/committed to revise by the government Indicator 2.5.1: Extent of which legal, policy and institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems

2.1No any climate change policy identified or committed by the government yet. 2.5In terms of policies and regulations, Xinjiang Forestry Department submitted an official document [2015 No.643] with the topic as ‘The letter of forestry legislation plan of 2016 report’ to the autonomous region government legislative affairs, general office of the autonomous region government policies ‘The notice of concerning the legislation in autonomous region government in 2016 work plan’ included the Kalamaili regulation in the legislation plan. After that the XFD delivered another official letter[2016 No.96] about Kalamaili Management Regulation to each state and municipality for consultation. Substantive progress has been made in establishing of “One NR One Regulation”.

Indicator 1.1: Set up effective governance and legal framework of PA system in XUAR. Indicator 1.2: Evaluate and revise the main relevant sectoral plan, including the introduction of EIA requirements, more consultation, restoration and ecological compensation. Rules-based to PA manager and industry leaders, including "Best Practice “guidelines and sustainable management and financial plan.
Indicator 1.3: Establish information and data sharing platform under the supervision of XFD, support the operability of PA management. Indicator 2.1: AMWL PA system is expanded, more effective; clear management plan for PA system developed. Indicator 2.2: Relevant professional training is available for key department and PA staff on themes incl. biodiversity and wildlife monitoring, PA management, restoration, co-management, etc; Ecological Health Index tool developed and used by PA managers to monitor environmental trends, with appropriate training. Indicator 2.3: Enhanced inter-sectoral dialogue at prefecture level, with AMWL coordination group established organizing bi-annual forum; The economic value of water and biodiversity, and of PAs and the ecological services they protect, more widely recognized by the public and government, based on a targeted (wetland focus) economic valuation of biodiversity and the AMWL PA system. Indicator 2.4: Public awareness of PAs and value of wetland services is enhanced through media campaigns, interpretative strategy, guidebook Indicator 2.5: Cooperation with Mongolia helps to integrate Chinese portion of Altai Mountains within the broader ecoregional landscape. Indicator 3.1: Threats to biodiversity better understood, based on more in-depth assessment of threats including mining and grazing; Practical upgrading of PA staff abilities with training courses and also joint field work; Development of sound community co-management structures, including regular participatory forum, and an agreed EHI monitoring system; Degraded land restored w

Indicator 2.1.3: Extent to which adopted regulations, ordinances and standards bring about stronger biodiversity protection Indicator 2.5.2: Extent to which capacities to implement national and local plans for integrated Sustainable Bio-Energy Development management, or to protect and conserve the energy ecosystems have improved

2.1.3 In the HLJ, a vigorous drive launched by the HLJ PMU to promote and disseminate the HLJ Wetland Protection Regulation (revised edition, 2015) that was approved by HLJ People’s Congress in Oct. 2015; In the IM, the development of the IM DXAL Wetland Protection Regulation has been planned and budgeted. Besides, a technical guideline has been drafted by the national project and will be introduced on trial in DXAL landscape to regulate various activities, e.g. tourism, agriculture, mining around PAs. 2.5.2 By implementing the UNDP/GEF project, capacities to implement national and local plans for the protection and conservation of the energy ecosystems have been improving remarkably. Within the reporting period, various types of training activities were delivered for PA staff and governmental authorities engaged in wetland protection both locally and abroad, e.g. at Mai Po, Canada and USA, to raise capacities in protecting and conserving the ecosystems. Training curricula covers PA management planning, wetland protection and biodiversity monitoring and evaluation, EHI, etc. More than 200 person-time were trained and certificated.

Inner Mongolia section average of 37 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases 2014 Heilongjiang section average of 4 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases 2014
In 2014 the Heilongjiang region assigned more than 3700 peopletimes and more than 1350 vehiclestimes to inspect criminal cases related to biodiversity conservation on the market restaurants and other establishments inspected 680 sites Besides a total of 118 unauthorized visitorsvillagers were expelled from the PAs more than 3500 passing vehicles were inspected 870 hunting gear were impounded more than 170 live birds released 8 wildlife and wild animal products were impounded and 4 wildlife cases were uncovered
In the Inner Mongolia area there was no criminal case found in PAs during this period thanks to the strengthened enforcement of relevant laws regulations and policies by both the authorities and local people that has been greatly promoted and supported by the project For example Hanma National Reserve strengthened the monitoring and publicity developed relevant work processes systems and management practices developed a wildlife patrol monitoring system and carried out regular inspection supervision and guidance of the implementation A total of 30 automatic infrared cameras have been emplaced for effective monitoring in populous areas of wildlife 16 additional wildlife monitoring sites have been established Furthermore several special reports and articles had been published for raising the public awareness At the Erguna NNR 5 times patrolling were carried out into the mountain areas removed 2 sets of hunting gear evicted 24 persontimes of people illegally entered into the protected areas for construction exploration hunting and fishing purposes

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration
Indicator 2.3 (Ha) land under protection Indicator 2.1 (3): Number of biodiversity policy (regulations, ordinances, guidelines, etc.) identified and taken up/committed to revise by the government

comment.narrative: From the Second Wetland Resources Survey, which was released in December of 2014, the wetland area in Anhui Province is 1.04 million ha, accounting for around 7.47% of the total territory of the province. Till late 2016, there are 1 Ramsar site, 23 wetland NRs, 46 wetland parks, with protected wetland total area of 479,000 ha, accounting for around 3.44% of the total territory of the province and 45% of all wetlands. A new planned development project, which might threaten several lakes, is the construction of a canal from the Yangtze River to Hefei via Caizi Lake. This will cause marked changes to the water level regime of this critical lake. The government promised to keep the natural water level in winter for migrant birds and the project is pending due to the central governmental policy about “integrated conservation, no unsustainable development” on Yangtze River ecological environment conservation. The State Council published the System and Methods on Wetland Conservation and Restoration and Anhui will follow the methods in 2017.
Indicator 2.3 (Ha) land under protection Indicator 2.1 (3): Number of biodiversity policy (regulations, ordinances, guidelines, etc.) identified and taken up/committed to revise by the government

2.3 WPA coverage increased 12,143.82 ha in 2016.
2.1 Till the end of 2016, 479,517 ha PAs for the whole province are under protection. (Chao Lake with 78795.53 ha is counted in this time.) Management Rules/Methods on Shenjin Lake had been approved by Chizhou municipal government in December 2016.
Wetland Conservation Plan of Anhui Province (2016~2030) was approved by provincial government in Sep. 2016.
Anhui Wetland Conservation Regulation was enacted from Jan. 1, 2016

(1) With supports from all the stakeholders, the Provincial Consultative Group was established; the first group meeting and the third PSC meeting was held; some major decisions adjustments were made; and consultants’ reports were reviewed. (2) The area of WPA in Hubei was increased, more wetlands were protected and benefit from ecosystem-based management. (3) Wetland conservation strategy of Hubei Province drafted and under review. Five sub-strategies were also formulated on the basis of the Wetland Conservation Strategy of Hubei Province, targeting on five priority areas of Hubei biodiversity, to integrate a high level strategy of Hubei. (4) Provincial wetlands database system was launched. (5) Provincial policy framework improved. Gap Analysis and Legislative Proposals of Laws and Regulations System on Wetland Protection in Hubei Province was drafted, a review panel was held to revise the report. (1) The second Honghu Watershed Management Council meeting was held in Jinzhou city. (2) Mid-term value assessment of water quality of target WPA Honghu has been carried out, water quality has improved slightly compared with the baseline. (3) Wetland conservation strategy of Honghu Watershed was drafted, a review panel was held to revise the report. (4) Honghu Master Plan was drafted and revised and submitted to SFA. (5) The fishing nets of 180,000 Mu in Honghu have been removed from the lake, fishermen were resettled from the lake to the land. (1) Capacity Development Score for HFD, HAD and HEPD greatly improved and HFD has already achieved the project target. (2) EHI baseline mid-term value and METT mid-term value show significant improvements. (3) The provincial wetland ecosystem management trainings were held successfully. (4) Management plan, business plan and monitoring plan were drafted and are under review. (5) 4 model WPAs have set up local consultative committees and 2 have signed the management agreements.

Output 1 Indicators: 1. Provincial wetlands conservation consultative group; 2. a)Wetlands Conservation Strategy of Hubei Province mandating inter-agency support for WPA conservation is approved by relevant provincial authorities; b)operational reduces threats to WPA biodiversity conservation from production sectors (fishers, agriculture, tourism) 3. a)Planning adopted and funded by relevant provincial authorities mandating; b)operational reduces threats to WPA biodiversity conservation from production sectors (fishers, agriculture, tourism) Output 2 Indicators. 1. Intra-basin wetlands conservation consultative group established with official terms of reference approved by relevant provincial and county authorities. 2. Formulate biodiversity conservation strategy for Honghu watershed; b) reduction in pollution (Nitrogen and Phosphorous) at Honghu by at least 15% Output 3 Indicators: 1. UNDP Capacity scorecard for Hubei's WPA's improves by 20%, 2. a）commission be approved by relevant provincial and county authorities.；b）increase percentage of women participating as voting members of key WPA consultative forums 3. Establish co-management institution 4. Formulate or improvement conservation management plan for globally significant species in 8 model WPA 5. Business plans result in 25% increase in annual government financing for four WPA's with improve business 6. Monitoring plan of 8 WPA and distribution status of conservation objectives for globally significant species.

1. Ensuring Sustainable Regional and National Cooperation for Ecosystem-Based Management 2. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with Respect to Provisioning Services 3. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with respect to Regulating and Cultural Services 4. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with respect to Supporting Services

comment.narrative: Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem is a water body bordered by China, RO Korea and DPR Korea, covering an area of 400,000 km2. Rivers discharge about 1.6 billion tons of sediment and 1,500 billion tones of freshwater into the Yellow Sea. The low flushing rate between Yellow Sea and East China Sea of one every seven years, combined with weak water circulation, makes this sea vulnerable to pollution and its coastal areas highly susceptible to localized pollution discharges. Qingdao, Dalian, Shanghai, Seoul/Incheon (RO Korea) and Pyongyang/Nampo (DRP Korea) are the five cities with over tens of millions of inhabitants bordering the sea. This population replies on the Yellow Sea LME’s ecosystem carrying capacity to provide capture fisheries resources in excess of two million tonnes per year, mariculture over 14 million tonnes per year, support for wildlife, provision of bathing beaches and tourism, and its capacity to absorb nutrients and other pollutants. Yet fishing efforts increased threefold between the 1960s and early 1980s, during which time the proportion of demersal species, such as small and large yellow croakers, hairtail, flatfish and cod, declined by more than 40 percent in terms of biomass. Other major transboundary problems include increasing discharge of pollutants; changes to ecosystem structure leading to an increase in jellyfish and harmful algal blooms; 40 percent loss of coastal wetlands from reclamation and conversions projects. Severe environmental degradation has cost the country approximately nine percent of its gross national income in 2009 . This situation has been further exacerbated by incomplete legislation and insufficient enforcement. The environmental foundation needed to sustain economic growth may be irreversibly altered, and the important human health implications of a deteriorating environment such as increased agriculture and food contamination and air and water pollution, have resulted in a series of efforts to improve the environme

1. Ensuring Sustainable Regional and National Cooperation for Ecosystem-Based Management 2. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with Respect to Provisioning Services 3. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with respect to Regulating and Cultural Services 4. Improving Ecosystem Carrying Capacity with respect to Supporting Services

1. A draft regional guidelines for the involvement of stakeholder groups for the implementation of the Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem Strategic Action Programme was prepared for review and adoption by the 1st meeting of the Interim Commission Council to be held in 1st quarter of 2017. The guidelines describe the structure, functions and rules of procedures of subsidiary bodies of the Commission
Inter-Ministerial Coordinating Committees are already established in both China and RO Korea and will be fully functional in approval of annual workplan and TORs of the Interim Commission Council and its subsidiary bodies in the implementation of the Project.
A document entitled Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem Partnership is prepared for adoption at the 1st meeting of the YSLME Interim Commission Council. The documents will guide the eligibility, procedure, roles and responsibilities, in implementation of the YSLME SAP. NOWPAP, PEMSEA, UNESCAP East Asia, EAAFP, CI China, WWF Japan, IW:Learn, IOC/WESTPAC, KIOST, KOEM, NMEMC (China), FIO/SOA, CIMA/SOA, China-PEMSEA Sustainable Coastal Development Center, China Ocean University, YSFRI/CAFS, Qingdao Municipal Government, Dalian Municipal Government, Incheon Municipal Government, Rongcheng Municipal Government have or will participate in the implementation of the SAP. Partnership with private sectors and more NGOs will be further explored during inception phase. 2.China has set the national targets to reduce 20,000 fishing boats with a total capacity of 1.5 million kW and reduce fish landings by 15 percent during 13th FYP. Specific fishing boat reduction target for Yellow Sea is under development. In addition, a universal fishing moratorium in Chinese coastal waters from May 1 to Sept 16 will be imposed by Ministry of Agriculture to restore the declining fish stock. 3.Since 2016 China has initiated Blue Bay Action Plan incentivizing local governments to adopt integrated approaches to address coastal and marine challeng

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Systemic and institutional framework for PWS development and management established at municipal and provincial levels for the Chishui River Basin within Guizhou Province. 2. Pilot PWS scheme(s) are demonstrated in selected sub-watersheds of the Chishui River Basin in Guizhou Province.

comment.narrative: 1. Weak enabling framework and institutional capacity for PWS implementation and upscaling 2. Insufficient know-how on the establishment and implementation of viable PWS mechanisms for biodiversity conservation

Output1: 1. For establishing and implementing PWS mechanism along Chishui river within Guizhou, the Guizhou Sub-Project Management Office (SPMO) was established in Guizhou Academy of Environmental Science and Designing (GAESD) which is under the management of Guizhou EPD during the first quarter of 2015. The director of Ecology Conservation Division is in charge of daily operation of the SPMO. There are six staffs involved in SPMO part or full time. The SPMO was directed and hosted by Guizhou EPD which is also responsible for the watershed eco-compensation management in Guizhou at present. At the end of this project, a part of the SPMO will be transferred to Chishui River PWS Management Office which will be hosted by Guizhou EPD. (Because most of the SPMO members are staff of Guizhou EPD already, which just need mainstreaming efforts, unnecessary to sign an agreement). 2. The CTA ,international consultant Dr. Julio and experts from WWF, TNC, Wanxiang Trust Fund and Chinese Academy of Environmental Planning provide a training on PWS and water fund to local enterprises, EPB staffs and local community of Renhuai and Wuma on 11th July, 2016. With the establishment of PWS mechanism, more training will be organised to improve the management and implementation capacities of local staffs on PWS. Capacity Development Scorecard at 30 June 2016: Guizhou EPD: 60% Bijie EPB: 50% Chishui EPB: 50% Renhuai EPB: 55% Zunyi EPB: 50%. Bijie EPB: 50% Chishui EPB: 50% Renhuai EPB: 55% Zunyi EPB: 50%
3.To improve capacities of provincial and municipal environmental protection offices for implementing PES/PWS, series of training workshops have been carried out during the past year. The staffs of provincial and municipal environmental protection offices understand more about the concepts of PWS. With the establishment of PWS mechanism in 2016, more training will be organised to improve the management and implementation capacities of local staffs on PWS. 4.T

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Development of action plan of comprehensive public campaign to promote LED products and manufacturers. 2. Completion of an international exhibition of LED technologies and industries; 3. Conduct a series of workshops and forums to develop the dialogues and partnership among industry, administration and customers. 4. Development of implementation plan to organize the national technology innovation competition; 5. Public awareness of the event and follow-ups. 6. Learning the national and foreign policies and regulations, the personnel capability requirement and the current status through the investigation. 7. Development of training courses on energy conservation management for government agencies. 8. Survey and evaluation of current relationship and liaison between industry and academic society.

comment.narrative: 1. the understanding od domestic and abroad users on LED enterprises in China is weak, especially on the energy efficiency situation, quality of the products, and technological levels, etc. 2. There is lack of good channels in disseminating the best practices of technology innovations for Chinese LED enterprises. In the existing technology innovation completion and relevant public promotion campaigns, LED has never been involved as an independent sector. 3. Energy management of government agencies has been listed in the important items on energy conservation of China. Obviously the problem that lacking of the competent personnel on energy conservation in government agencies has caused concern, 4. Although a pert of the personnel of government agencies have taken the training of the knowledge on energy conservation, the systematic training pf policies and regulations interpretation and practice capability are badly needed at present. 5. The understanding about the development of LED technologies in other countries is weak, especially the study of advanced LED technologies through study tours abroad and trainings inside China is very weak.

description.narrative: The PIP consists of the project preparatory activities such as: (1) Conduct of studies and surveys to come up with the pertinent data and information that are required to verify and confirm the earlier identified baseline projects on, and barriers to, the widespread application of energy efficient green logistics techniques and practices in the logistics industry; (2) Conduct of a logical framework analysis (LFA) mainly to verify and firm up the project planning matrix (PPM) or results framework (log frame); (3) Identification and assessment of demonstrations for the manufacturing and application of improved SSL products; (4) Detailed design of the project components and activities (includes evaluation and analyses of the results of, and data/information derived from, the studies and surveys conducted for use in the design of specific project activities; basic design of demonstration projects, estimation of potential energy savings and CO2 emission reduction, project activities budgeting, etc.); (5) Conduct of stakeholder and project partner coordination meetings (e.g., demonstration hosts and co-financers), and establishment of the appropriate project implementation and management arrangements; (6) Preparation of the UNDP-GEF Project Document (ProDoc) and GEF CEO Endorsement Request (CER) Document based on the GEF-approved project concept, i.e., GEF-approved PIF (Annex 1); and, (7) Finalization of the ProDoc and CER Document. The final output of this PIP is the approved UNDP-GEF Project Document and GEF CEO Endorsement Request Document.

comment.narrative:
As part of Denmark’s focus on South-South Cooperation, to enable better and more coherent cooperation between China and countries in Africa, in particular around the promotion of the UN’s Sustainable Energy for All initiative(SE4ALL), UNDP China has been funded to develop this project document. The project proposal has been developed with the Zambian Ministry of Mines, Energy and Water Development, China’s Ministry of Science and Technology and the advice of stakeholders from government, the private sector and research institutions in Zambia and China. The project aims to support the access to electricity for rural communities in Zambia. It will do so through the creation of an enabling environment to up-scale renewable energy technology deployment. This includes removing market barriers for introduction of improved renewable energy technologies and the strengthening of South – South Cooperation between Zambia and China.
1.1 Draft review report of the implementation of policies and legislation for rural electrification using off-grid technologies exists. Current legislation ineffective and incomplete. 1.2 Financial mechanisms insufficient (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 2.1 Testing and training centers not equipped and functional (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 2.2 Capacity gaps exist (baseline: UNDP scoping mission to Zambia 2013) 3.1 Knowledge gaps exist (baseline: UNDP / MOST dialogue 2013) 3.2 Chinese Center for South-South Cooperation within MOST does not exist 4.1 Project management structures not in place.
Zambia has the second largest potential for solar power in the world, currently virtually unused, and an abundance of rivers and water resources in the rural areas. Building on this potential, solar- and hydro power are identified as the most appropriate renewable energy technologies for Zambia and thus consistent with the Chinese development experience. The project seeks to achieve three strategic outcomes; i) Strength

1. Establish the management team of project. 2. Start the research for evaluation of the implementation effectiveness of pollution prevention and control policies. 3. Establish LPMO. 4. Organize the Inception workshop.

1. The steering groups were established in national level and one technical expert, one policy expert and one coordinator is employed on December, 2016. 2. The research for evaluation of the implementation effectiveness of pollution prevention and control policies is started on December, 2016. 3. LPMO is been built on December 2016. 4. The Inception workshop is held in 12th Nov and more than 70 representatives from GEF, UNDP, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, Ministry of Environmental Protection, Development Research Center of State Council, environmental protection department and industry associations, scientific research institutions and related enterprises of demonstration provinces participated the meeting.

Target 1: 1.1. Carry out the research for evaluation of the implementation effectiveness of pollution prevention and control policies. 1.2. Start the research on evaluating the economic effectiveness of secondary nom-ferrous metal industry in China. 1.3. Carry out the research on Assessment Indicator System and Audit Guideline of Cleaner Production in Secondary Copper Smelting Industry. 1.4. Carry out the research on application and issuance technical guideline for discharge permit on secondary non-ferrous metal industry. 1.5. Strengthen the capacity for supervision and management Target 2: 2.1 Start the selection of BAT/BEP demonstration enterprises. 2.2 Determine the BAT/BEP demonstration scheme. 2.3 Sign the demonstration contracts.

Result1: 1. The research for evaluation of the implementation effectiveness of pollution prevention and control policies is started on December, 2016. The recommendations for improvement together with technical policy draft were completed on November, 2017. 2. The research on evaluating the economic effectiveness of secondary nom-ferrous metal industry in China is started on June, 2017. The evaluation and policy recommendations will be finished by 2018. 3. The research on assessment indicator system and audit guideline of cleaner production in secondary copper smelting industry is started on June, 2017. As one output of this sub-project, the technical specification of “The cleaner production evaluation index system for secondary copper industry” has been consulted for the whole society by NDRC in September, 2017 and it is expected to officially be issued in near future. 4.The research on application and issuance technical guideline for discharge permit on secondary non-ferrous metal industry has started on December, 2017. The related guideline is expected be finished on April, 2018 5. Special inspection of dioxin pollution prevention for secondary copper enterprises in Jiangxi province is launched by LPMO. Result2: 2.1 Two secondary copper smelting enterprises were selected as demonstration enterprises on July, 2017. 2.2 Technologies for BAT/BEP demonstration have been confirmed through much discussion by FECO, the candidate demonstration enterprises and relevant experts. A total of 3 techniques for different copper scrape will be demonstrated in these two enterprises. 2.3 Contract negotiation with these two candidate demonstration enterprises was conducted and the contracts were signed on December, 2017.

comment.narrative: Gansu’s PAs continue to provide multiple biodiversity benefits, ecosystem services, and tourism opportunities, but in steadily declining amounts as processes of environmental degradation spread and deepen.Opportunities to conserve globally significant biodiversity are missed at most of Gansu’s 58 PAs IEFAs, due to lack of sufficient capacity and lack of sufficient revenue for effective nature reserves management, unplanned development, conflicts between different government sectoral departments, and unsustainable resource use (particularly overgrazing).

comment.narrative: According to survey data (unpublished) from the Third Institute of Oceanography of SOA, the CWD was distributed continuously along the Chinese southeast coast from Wenzhou, Zhejiang, some 60 years ago; since when the distribution range has been fragmented with several isolated local populations formed, and migration routes and individual exchanges between the five local populations remaining unknown at present. The population sizes in Ningde waters, Quanzhou Bay and Dongshan Bay in Fujian Province, as well as Shantou waters in Guangdong Province still need further investigation.

1.1.1： Organize the Inception meeting and the 1st meeting of Project Steering Committee (PSC) 1.1.2： Organize the 2nd meeting of Project Steering Committee (PSC) 1.1.3： Research on international ABS focuses and national experience of foreign countries and ABS case studies 1.1.4： Case studies on foreign bio-prospecting in China 1.1.5：National field survey, international study tour on ABS and participation in international workshop and conference on ABS 1.1.6： Organize Consulting and Reviewing meetings for all research activities under the outcome 1, and participation relevant workshops 1.1.7 Communications between various stakeholders 1.1.8 Report printing 1.1.9 Research on preparation for the Nagoya Protocol National Implementation Program 1.4.1: Research on ABS clearing-house mechanism 2.1.1 Public awareness raising material preparation, and training organizing consultant 2.1.2 public awareness raising activities, and participation relevant workshops 3.3.2 Application case procedures in pilots of Yunnan， Guangxi and Hunan Province, including the negotiation, agreements, contracts, governmental approval, contract implementation, compliance, monitoring, etc. 3.4.2 Disseminate materials of experience of the pilots in international conferences, including organize side events in COP-14 (2018) and (COP-15, 2020) for publicity of the project's experience on demonstration internationally.

1.1.1The inception meeting and the 1st PSC meeting were convened on June 17, 2016 in Beijing and attended by participants from ministries, institutions and companies, including representatives from pilot provinces—Guangxi, Yunnan and Hunan. 17 out of 47 participants are women. The Two-Year Work Plan was discussed and approved by PSC 1.1.2To be held in Q1, 2017 1.1.3An international consultant is being recruited through UNDP 1.1.4ToR for individual expert has been finished and is now going through approval formalities. 1.1.5Study tour to one of biodiversity mega country—South Africa was conducted in July 2016 1.1.6Meetings were arranged 1.1.7Discussion between national PMO and Provincial PMOs on contracts to be signed 1.1.8Print-out of Project Document in both English and Chinese 1.1.9Clearing house and public participation and international cooperation etc. several aspects have been prepared by the project and submitted to the Department of Nature and Ecology Conservation, MEP and for their review and clearance for announcement/publication 1.4.1China’s national ABS clearing-house website (www.absch.org.cn) was restructured and updated in both the layout and contents. 2.1.1Proposal submitted to the Department of Nature and Ecology Conservation of MEP, for their review 2.1.2On September 28, 2016, a one-day training was organized in Beijing, which was attended by nearly 40 trainees, who were stakeholders coming from provincial environmental protection bureaus, enterprises, research institutions, academia and media, among them one fourth are women. The training provided with trainees a wide spectrum of information ranging from ABS protocol to relevant national laws, from related company practices to experiences and lessons learnt from other countries. 3.3.2PMO will, as planned, support pilots to carry out the task in 2017 3.4.2ABS promotional materials have been disseminated in COP13 in Cancun, Dec. 2016.

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration
1. PA system consolidation and institutional strengthening. 2. Emplacement of effective PA management and incentivizing participatory conservation.

comment.narrative: Qighai province has an extensive PA system, covering about one-third of the Province’s land surface, and harbouring important habitats for endangered species such as snow leopard. The government invests $6.5 million annually for managing the PA system. Some national government-led eco-compensation programmes exist in Qinghai, including Sanjiangyuan Ecological Construction Programme and Grassland Eco-compensation Programme. Currently the use of these funding systems remains geared mostly towards engineering-oriented water schemes or some short-term measures; or toward reducing grazing pressure.
1. PA system consolidation and institutional strengthening. 2. Emplacement of effective PA management and incentivizing participatory conservation.

Support deliver all measures to ensure full coverage of compulsory education and other activities envisaged. 3.
